Based on the search results, I found information about the 1973 Polish film "Chłopi" (The Peasants) directed by Jan Rybkowski. Here's what I discovered:

The film "Chłopi" is a 1973 Polish historical film directed by Jan Rybkowski. It is based on the novel "Chłopi" by Władysław Reymont, for which Reymont received the 1924 Nobel Prize in Literature.

The 1973 film is actually a cinema version of a television series from 1972. The film stars Władysław Hańcza, Emilia Krakowska, Krystyna Królówna, and Krystyna Kołodziejczyk.

The film is an adaptation of Władysław Reymont's Nobel Prize-winning novel, depicting a world based on the epic "Chłopi" that is confined to the boundaries of one village, with the drama of events following the rhythm of changing seasons and the rhythm of field work and village rituals.

The plot involves a beautiful girl who makes both a rich farmer and his son fall in love with her, causing considerable confusion in the village. The story focuses on the Boryna family and other villagers in the Mazovia region of Poland at the turn of the 19th/20th centuries, where the Borynas are farmers and their son is expected to follow the family tradition.

Director Jan Rybkowski was noted as a skilled filmmaker, with excellent actor selection, particularly highlighting the performances of Władysław Hańcza and Emilia Krakowska. The film has a runtime of 2 hours and 46 minutes and was released on December 7, 1973 in Poland.
